name: Armodafinil (Nuvigil)
summary: A wakefulness-promoting medication used to treat excessive sleepiness associated with narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea, and shift work sleep disorder.
description: Armodafinil is the R-enantiomer of modafinil, with a longer half-life and potentially more sustained wakefulness-promoting effects. It is FDA-approved for the treatment of excessive daytime sleepiness due to narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and shift work sleep disorder (SWSD). Its exact mechanism is unclear but is thought to involve modulation of dopaminergic signaling via dopamine transporter inhibition.

contraindications: Known hypersensitivity to armodafinil, modafinil, or formulation excipients

items: Excessive daytime sleepiness due to obstructive sleep apnea

sections.text: Inhibits dopamine reuptake by binding to the dopamine transporter (DAT), increasing extracellular dopamine and promoting wakefulness; may also affect other neurotransmitter systems.

adult.start: 150–250 mg orally once daily in the morning for narcolepsy and OSA; 150 mg taken ~1 hour before work shift for SWSD

sections.geriatric: Lower starting dose (e.g., 150 mg) may be appropriate
sections.hepatic_impairment: Reduce dose by half in severe impairment

sections.text: Onset within 1–2 hours; duration of effect up to 12–15 hours.

serious: psychiatric symptoms such as mania or hallucinations

other: Use caution in patients with history of cardiovascular disease or psychiatric illness
Risk of rash including SJS/TEN; discontinue immediately if rash appears

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; consider potential teratogenicity
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in breast milk; use caution
sections.geriatrics: Use lower initial doses and monitor closely

sections.text: Not typically required, but gradual discontinuation may be considered to minimize rebound sleepiness.

items: Armodafinil is the R-enantiomer of modafinil, potentially offering a longer duration of action.
Not a substitute for primary treatment of OSA (e.g., CPAP).
Lower abuse potential than amphetamines, but still a Schedule IV controlled substance.
